Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an X-ray Diffractometer for Research and Training in Chemical Structure-Function Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program, the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR). Professor George Richter-Addo from the University of Oklahoma and colleagues Daniel Glatzhofer, Robert Cichewicz, Indrajeet Sharma and Bayrammurad Saparov are acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer. X-ray diffraction is a powerful tool to investigate the atomic structure of solid materials. It is used to understand how the atoms are arranged and bonded to each other in a material. The knowledge of the atomic structures of materials is fundamental to understanding their properties and developing improvements. The applications of microscopic structural knowledge ranges from chemistry to biology, materials and medicine, to applications such as developing better agrochemicals, electronic devices or pharmaceuticals. The instrument advances the training of students in research and is also employed in the annual Sooner Upward Bound program each summer that brings in inner-city (OKC) high school students at high risk for academic failure. This acquisition also assists research and training at five other partner Oklahoma institutions: Oklahoma State University, Northeastern State University, Southeastern State University, University of Science and Arts and Southwestern Oklahoma State University.

This diffractometer advances research and education at the University of Oklahoma and surrounding area. It helps in identifying reactive molecular-level, metallo-intermediates in the global nitrogen cycle and developing new families of semiconductor materials and photovoltaics. The instrumentation is also used to characterize intermediates for organic transformations and applications in asymmetric synthesis. Researchers are developing semi- and total-synthesis methodologies and determining the absolute stereochemistry of natural products. This diffractometer is essential to determine the crystal structures of solid-state metal oxides/sulfides and organoactinide complexes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Knowing the three-dimensional structures of molecules and materials allows for a deeper understanding of their properties and, subsequently, their function. The structure-function theme is an important one in all of chemistry, and is of strategic importance to the research community. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography enables the study of chemical structure in atomic detail that, in turn, allows elucidation of chemical structure-function relationships. The PI and co-PIs at the University of Oklahoma, and the users from other institutions in Oklahoma, have recognized programs that require the use of X-ray crystallography to determine the three-dimensional structures of target molecules and materials. CHE-1726630 funding from the NSF Major Research Instrumentation program allowed us to acquire a modern small-molecule X-ray diffractometer with a micro-focus beam and high brilliance optics to accelerate the productivity of several Oklahoma research groups and pursue new research goals, and attract new researchers to employ X-ray crystallography to help guide their chemical structure-function studies. In addition, by acquiring this instrument, we were able to provide a better understanding and utility of crystallography to students, through hands-on educational and research training activities involving students.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Acquisition of the new X-ray diffractometer allowed us to probe molecular structures and interactions in atomic detail. Importantly, crystal structural information has been, and continues to be, critical to the development of several structure-function research programs in Oklahoma. Our significant results for this award cycle included: (i) identification of chemical models of reactive metallo-intermediates in the global nitrogen cycle of relevance to NSF's Innovations at the Nexus of Food, Environment, and Water Systems (INFEWS) program, (ii) development of new families of easy-to-process semiconductor materials and photovoltaics made from halide and chalcogenide precursors, (iii) characterization of new reaction intermediates for organic transformations and applications in asymmetric synthesis, (iv) development of new semi- and total-synthesis methodology for, and determining the absolute stereochemistry of, natural products, and (iv) determination of the crystal structures of new solid-state metal oxide/sulfide complexes for the development of spectral signatures for these structure types.

BROADER IMPACTS: At the time of its purchase, the new instrument was the only functioning small-molecule diffractometer in the State of Oklahoma. In addition to the 8 research groups from local labs that used the instrument, several research groups from 4 other institutions within the State (OK State Univ., Northeastern State Univ., Univ. of Science and Arts of OK, Univ. of OK Health Sciences Center), and from 8 other institutions outside the State (Univ. of Arkansas, Univ. of Central Arkansas, Penn State Univ. Altoona, Fitchburg State Univ., Univ. of Nebraska, Jackson State Univ., Florida Inst. Technol., and Univ. of Southern Mississippi) utilized the instrument for X-day data collection. During the grant period, 14 research manuscripts were published, and 45 conference presentations were held, that utilized the resulting structural data. In addition, the structural data contributed to 14 Ph.D. dissertations, 2 M.S. theses, and 4 undergraduate theses.

The lab manager utilized the diffractometer in his graduate course (lecture and hands-on) at the University of Oklahoma. Several graduate students were trained to use the instrument. The PI and several participants actively engaged in programs that introduced at-risk high school students, and the general public, to modern science. Such activities included involvement in our annual Sooner Upward Bound (summer) program that brought in inner-city (OKC) high school students at high risk for academic failure; many of them were from low-income and disadvantaged backgrounds.
